lines: P R O C E E D I N G S
PRESIDENT:  Physical difference, as well as philosophical
difference -- if we might call it that -- is to say:
"Well, the elevator was blocked."
Respectfully, we submit that that is just a strange
way to disavow the actions of your own company, because
if the door was locked, why didn't you order it opened?
If you wanted to know what was going on at your own
company, why did you simply not ask?
A.  The third undisputed fact is that the Money Exchange
provided falsified financial statements to lenders,
including Kuwait Finance House.
PRESIDENT:  Sorry.  For the record, when you say "undisputed
facts", I think your view is that these cannot be
disputed on claimant's case, because respondent does
dispute those.  Is that my understanding?
A.  I would say not, because if you look at their pleadings,
they concede that the Money Exchange conducted a fraud.
They simply debate that is what was -- (overspeaking) --
Q.  -- we understand the position, but just to be clear,
because also some of the exhibits, especially the
resolution and the contract, some of them challenge the
documents provided by the parties.  We'll hear from them
on that?
A.  Certainly, Mr Chairman.
And with respect to some of those documents relating
to the transaction, we don't include those as undisputed
facts, we recognise they're disputed, we're really
pointing to things that, for example, they've put in
this in their own evidence.
CHAIRMAN:  Thank you.
MR HINES:  I think also you said that was an undisputed
fact, but that is a disputed fact.
MR WEBSTER:  They claim that it was, but they do not ever
claim that it was legally a separate and distinct
entity.
We submit, as I said, that's for good reason.
Opening submissions by MR IKRAM
MR IKRAM:  It is pretty clear that it is not, however.
There is testimony from Mr Charlton, who we'll hear
from tomorrow, that was submitted in the Cayman Islands'
proceedings, and he states here that the financial
statements that were produced by the auditors El Ayouty,
and they were falsified and that the Money Exchange
misrepresented the nature of its business.
And as we'll see, it's really very difficult for
them to dispute that the financial statements are false
when you look at the numbers in the light of everything
that happened.
So we submit that there's a good reason that while
they try to distance themselves from the facts, they
don't dispute the facts themselves.
The fourth is that AHAB's partners accepted annual
dividends and other benefits from the Money Exchange.
This is again from Mr Charlton's evidence, where he
notes 146 million which is actually in loans to AHAB and
its partners and nearly 100 million in dividends derived
from what he describes as the Money Exchange's
ostensible profit.
The Money Exchange for years subsidised the AHAB
partners' lavish lifestyle by paying their bills and
wages.  This is an extract from Yousef Algosaibi's
testimony from the transcripts that respondent was
recently ordered to produce.
So we would submit that even if you accept:
"Their case at face value and the way that they
portrayed how it was done, the Money Exchange, for the
most part, and the best that you can conclude."
Is effectively this, that for years the AHAB
partners stuck their head in the sand and their hands
out for money from the fraud that they concede
Mr Al Sanea perpetrated.
MR WEBSTER:  Is that a life-like representation?
MR HEITZMANN:  It is not.
MR IKRAM:  I think it's Mr Bean!
PRESIDENT:  But we also submit that that case should not be
accepted on it face, because as we'll go through, we
believe and we think the evidence shows clearly, that
the AHAB partners knew exactly what was going on,
authorised it, approved it, and were equally complicit
for several reasons.
Where we don't have any dispute was that KFH thought
it was dealing with the Money Exchange.  They state that
we were not and again, we've engaged that issue and
we're disputing that, but there really is no getting
around the evidence from KFH's own internal documents
that they believed they were dealing with AHAB.
Whether or not they were we can dispute with
respondent, but certainly that was their belief?
A.  We see here two excerpts from an internal memorandum
that proceeded the renewal of the line of credit under
the MMA that forms part of the basis of the dispute
here.
Q.  It's also not disputed that KFH wired $40 million to an
account that was held by the Money Exchange.
Again, their name is right on the documents.  These
are the SWIFT transactions.  These are the bank
statements that they produced and their case is not that
the money didn't go to an account held by the Money
Exchange, their case is simply that that was.
Really, AHAB's account is that it was essentially
a frolic by Mr Saud, but it is not, we submit, disputed
on the record that the account was actually held by the
Money Exchange, in name?
A.  It's also not disputed that AHAB has not given that
money back.
(Short break)
MR EGGERS:  They attended creditors' meetings and they
pursued their claims on the back of the promissory notes
in Saudi Arabia.  In fact, that forms the basis for one
of their admissibility defences.
So the fact that KFH has been chasing this debt for
a long time is not seriously disputed either.
It's not in dispute that the court, when rejecting
their claim, said that it was without prejudice to their
ability to bring it, that their claim would not lapse
simply by virtue of the denial.
Again, the significance of that, I think, it's fair
to say, is disputed, but the language and the ruling
itself, we submit, on the record, cannot be in dispute.
With that as the backdrop, we think that many of the
disputed issues in this case have very obvious
resolutions.
Now, I want to note now I want to note the following
again and again I want to note the following.  Typing in
some extra lines to see if everything is working okay.
Following this presentation of what we think should
not be in dispute, that though AHAB denies it was
complicit in the fraud, then it is from the respondent's
own evidence, that what they're presenting here is the
arguments they made at the Cayman Islands court.
What they're --
CHAIRMAN:  Just to be clear, because that's in the first
claim is in fraud on the conspiracy.  The fraud you're
referring to is the falsified statements, as we
understand.
MR EGGERS:  There are, I think, two components.
Yes, the gravamen of the claim is the falsified
financial statements and the reliance induced.  But part
of our fraud claim is also that their fraud didn't stop
with that, that for years they misled lenders like KFH.
CHAIRMAN:  That's important, because when you refer to that,
it might be helpful because we're going to also hear
from them on that.
When you address that, what is exactly the elements
of fraud you're relying on and when did you know about
that in that sense?  Because that also goes to the
limitation defence that you're claiming on your
counterclaim.
MR EGGERS:  Yes, Mr Chairman.  We acknowledged and we will
certainly get there when we get to the legal details of
our claim.
What they're discussing here is a resolution -- and
this just one of many -- that specifically directs the
falsification of the financial statements.  It's
capitalisation of interest on the loan, but in addition
it's the preparation of English language statements for
the purposes of showing third parties.
They refer here to making cutting adjustments to
both the assets and the liabilities and to adopt them to
suit the competitive figures for previous years.
Now, they note that in cross-examination, Yousef
Algosaibi was, in fact, in those matters beholden to the
likes of Suleiman, Ahmad and Abdulaziz.
However, in what you'll see becomes one of the
themes of their testimony, he simply indicated that he
didn't really understand it and he just signed it
because the elders, the partners, directed him to.
We respectfully submit that blaming the actions on
other AHAB partners -- be they decided or not -- cannot
serve to exculpate AHAB from liability.
CHAIRMAN:  What is the value of the evidence given in other
proceedings?  We will soon hear about Bahrain, Saudi
Arabia and the UK.
We know this, but what value specifically, and then
what is the test?  Is that subject to English law, in
terms of the evidential value of it, or a different law?
MR EGGERS:  I think the significance of the evidence is
a matter that the tribunal is certainly qualified to
give the weight it deserves.
When it comes to admissions of the parties, we would
submit that a party's admission, particularly when it's
being tested in cross-examination, in a legitimate court
of law, is something that should be given substantial
weight.
I think the documents themselves that were admitted
that respondent was ordered to produce, like any other
document, should be afforded the weight that the
tribunal believes they are due, based on the provenance
of those specific documents.
As to the test, we don't think that English law
evidentiary rules -- or, for that matter, any forum's
evidentiary rules -- be specifically applied, given that
this is an international arbitration.  We think that by
design, the evidentiary standards are looser because
there's no danger, for example, of a jury being misled.
The tribunal is all well qualified to understand the
evidence presented to it.
Once the weight has been given to that evidence,
however, the burden of proof on the claims and the
elements that must be met certainly are to be adjudged
under English law.
CHAIRMAN:  That is extremely helpful.
Just so we know, whenever you make any reference to
"proceedings", you're not arguing any element of
res judicata, because that is your position that it is
all pure evidence?
MR EGGERS:  Yes, Mr Chairman, absolutely.  It is simply
offered for evidence, not for a binding determination.
CHAIRMAN:  Thank you.
MR EGGERS:  Here to that point, we have admissions from Saud
Algosaibi, from his testimony on the stand -- and
I would note again not that this is a binding finding,
but certainly I think there's persuasive value to what
the jurists sitting in the room listening to this
evidence concluded.
But it's fair to say that they did not find the
evidence to be truthful at many points.
Nevertheless, just accepting it on its face, for
what Mr Algosaibi says, he's asked about the fact that
the Money Exchange had substantial borrowings, and that
those borrowings were eating up any income that it had.
He confirms, yes, we looked at documents that
shows that.
He's asked: don't you think it's strange for
a company that has no profits to be paying dividends?
And he first says: well, I think they do it in many
different ways, and he's challenged on that.
Then again, he falls back on the elder AHAB partners
saying: well, it's a continuation of tradition.  That's
how it's done.  He says: I didn't regard it as strange
or not.  It was just the practice.  It was my uncle's
call.  Before that, it was my father's call, so I just
followed what they did.
This again comes back to our point that even if you
were to accept the case that they put on, what they're
essentially telling you is that we were negligent in the
operations of our own business.  We didn't care what was
going on.  We just wanted the money.
We think this is reaffirmed by Yousef Algosaibi.
Again, he was asked, "Isn't the Money Exchange giving
its income or part of it to AHAB by declaring
dividends?"  Yes.  What was it going to be left with to
pay its borrowings?  And he simply says, "I don't know."
That, we say, is an odd posture for one of the
principals with an interest in the company.
What we thought, despite the attempts to place this
all on the elder partners, is that they actually
continued this process that was put in place at first by
Abdulaziz for a long, long period of time until the
fraud collapsed.
Each year you'll see that they issued these
resolutions to continue the accounting practices that
were put in place the prior year and to produce in the
English language what they refer to as the budget in the
same method as the prior year.
And these resolutions form the basis for their
auditors going along with this programme.
And they did this year after year after year.  You
see all these resolutions that say:
"Please adjust the books in the way that we've done
in the past, and also we authorise you to pay out
dividends."
That is in a context of a Money Exchange that has
no profits.  And this happened all the way up and until
the year 2008.
This is, again, from their own annex summarising
what they believe is relevant testimony.
What you see here is Saud Algosaibi asking:
"You signed this resolution every year.  What do you
mean you didn't know what it meant?  Weren't you
curious?"
At first his answer is a little difficult to follow,
but then he again says:
"Well, it's just something my father did in his
design and way of doing things.  My key concern was to
follow his footsteps.  We sign.  We get dividends.  We
sign it.  We get the money."
Again, in discussing the further resolutions, they
say that it was in fact signed by Suleiman, Yousef and
Saud and Mr Al Sanea.  Saud didn't recall signing it.
However, he again says: if I did, it was just to get
the money.
Again, with respect to a 2004 resolution:
"I have to sign, otherwise the dividends will not
be paid."
He says:
"Here we have the chief accountant [and that's
AHAB's chief accountant], third floor, head office, Omar
Saad involved.  We have Badr" --
Sorry.  I apologise.  Mr Badr is the one I was
referring to.  He's their financial adviser at the head
office who is involved:
"We have uncle.  One of the principals there, so
many times over the chief accountants want to get this
released and get it done."
Unsurprisingly, this factored to a great degree in
the Cayman Islands court decisions where they explain in
much more detail than we have time here, exactly the
nature of the accounting adjustments, the capitalisation
of interest and why this was fraudulent.
I'm not going to belabour the point on the slides.
We have them here simply to underscore that these
practices were intentionally designed to mislead third
parties at the same time that they were sucking profits
out of the company to their own benefit.
This discusses the English language silo for the
financial decision which is a pure construct where they
English statements, or the audit statements meant to
privately inform them of what as really going on were
still prepared each year by their accountants,
El Ayouty.
El Ayouty ultimately was a willing participate in
this, but at least in the early day I think this was not
without protest, and this I believe is one of the
exhibits that was just added to be disclosed several
weeks ago.
It's already from them in 1994 to Abdulaziz and he's
saying: I express my deep discomfort about the
situation.  I hope it's not going to become
a catastrophe.
It, in fact, as we know, in 2009, does become
a catastrophe.
He says:
"I was personally astonished in your attitude
towards Mr Al Sanea and when he was asking you to
discuss, I was accusing him.
In conclusion, please advise what you want out of
this.  It must be presented to all partners so they can
act accordingly."
That, of course, was not done -- at least acting
accordingly was not done.
Again, we have the Cayman Islands court explaining,
contextualising all of this evidence and noting that the
correspondence between El Ayouty and Abdulaziz was found
in the possession of Saud Algosaibi.
We also have them underscoring that Abdulaziz,
speaking on behalf of El Ayoury, did some false
accounting practices and we have them underscoring the
partners knew that the Money Exchange was making
representations to third parties about the false
statements of their accountants in the year 2003.
With that, I'm going to turn things over to my
colleague Mr Heitzmann who's going to discuss some of
the relationship between the Money Exchange actors and
AHAB's partnership and its actors as well as Kuwait
Finance House.
Opening submissions by MR HEITZMANN
MR HEITZMANN:  To the point, Mr President and members of the
tribunal, I'm going to start with the point of which is
on the screen, which is the joint engagement of the AHAB
partners and the employees of the work subdivision, the
Money Exchange, and we're going to start with Mark
Hayley, who is the defined as a key witness in the
Cayman proceedings.
He's the general manager of the Money Exchange and
you see on the screen, his witness statement since 1998,
he starts working there and until the very end, and he's
still there from the end and he's trying to explain in
his witness statement that the Money Exchange is working
independently of the rest of AHAB.
Then when you go to the paragraph 119 of his witness
statement, he explains that actually, he goes to see
Mr Badr on the third floor which is working on the
AHAB's back office he says to basically glean
information about the business initiatives and practices
under consideration by Mr Hayley.  They are also other
points to visit the third floor other reasons.
We're going to talk about that, but just when talk
about Mr Badr, Mr Hines mentioned his name earlier.
Mr Mark Hayley actually explains who he is in his
witness statement.  It's paragraph 117, and he says he
has been described as the deputy financial manager of
AHAB the property division manager, the investment
division which is part of the financial adviser and
financial consultant:
"In the end that by virtue of these roles, he acted
as a conduit through which the Money Exchange obtained
information requested by the banks from AHAB's head
office in relation to the following."
So he's really at the third floor of AHAB in the
same building where Mark Hayley is situated, and he's
gathering the information on business activities,
performance of AHAB's subsidiaries and all affiliates --
I'm quoting again 117 of the witness statement of
Mr Hayley.
He's providing information required by the Money
Exchange to produce its consolidated financial
statements and information requested by the Money
Exchange by the ratings agencies and obtaining the
signatures of the AHAB partners on facility
documentation relating to the financial businesses.
So there is coordination between AHAB partners
through Mr Badr at least also another person and the
other signatory actually of the amendment letter,
Mr Jamjoum, and we're going to talk about him a bit
later.
He's working with the Money Exchange, but he has
also access to the AHAB personnel and that's also in the
witness statement of Mr Hayley at paragraph 114.
So I was mentioning Mr Hayley's visit to the third
floor and telling you that there are also other reasons,
because sometimes banks actually visit AHAB.  They want
actually to meet AHAB partners and what is going to do,
he's going to coordinate meetings with the banks and
Mr Saud Algosaibi, the son of Mr Abdulaziz, one of the
founding partners.
So that's one example.  That's one of the few
exhibits that we were recently receiving from AHAB
following the tribunal's orders.
He's writing to Mr Al Sanea:
"You may remember that I had asked for an
appointment to see Mr Saud Sanea.  I am not able to find
where this has been confirmed.  Please make the
arrangement for that to be made."
And so forth.
You can see at the bottom we provide other examples
of these visits.  On the next slide, you see actually
the visitors scheduled, the actual attendance list, and
again other examples at the bottom.
So you can see all this is happening with Mark
Hayley, Mr Saud Algosabi coordinating visits with the
banks, the banks representatives, they want to see AHAB,
the face of AHAB.
They want to see the Pepsi Cola factory.  It's
a cash money -- cash making asset for AHAB and they want
to understand.
So as we see on the next slide, Mr Hayley, who's one
of the key witnesses of AHAB in the case, he is there
until the claimant leaves, and he continues to work
throughout until 2016 with AHAB for the proceedings, the
Money Exchange of course is shutdown in 2009, but he's
continuing and he will testify in 2016 in the Cayman
proceedings on AHAB's side.
Now, all this is only the tip of the iceberg.  We
will see other examples of what happens to the joint
engagement of the AHAB partners with the Money Exchange,
in particular in the late months of the life of the
Money Exchange in early 2009, we will see a lot of
activity involving the partners, including Dawood,
signing many bank of China documents to indicate that
they will be confirming the authenticity of the bank
documentation.
Now, we are going to talk about the engagement with
KFH, and here on the screen you see an internal
memorandum translated from Arabic, that is in
March 2008, where actually KFH mentions when
recommending to extend the $70 million Murabaha
agreement facility that it is important to highlight the
longstanding relationship between the bank KFH and
Algosaibi which has spanned 13 years with over
24 Murabaha transactions renewed every six months.
15 years will go back to 1993.
We have actually an exhibit on the record which is
C-076, which is document of the first Murabaha
agreements where AHAB is a guarantor.
Now, we see also that KFH's relationship is also
with the AHAB partners.  KFH is not dealing only with
Mark Hayley and the Money Exchange employees.
They receive actual letters from AHAB's partners
Money Exchange and this is an example where Suleiman and
Saud Algosaibi in 2003 informed KFH about the exchanges
in the management of the Money Exchange following the
death of Abdulaziz.
You can see we provide many other examples of
employers to Money Exchange co-signed by Suleiman and
Saud, but this one is written to KFH a few months later
you still have them from Mr Suleiman also about the
changes to the Algosaibi partnership and board of the
Money Exchange.
So obviously the AHAB partners know that's who is
managing the Money Exchange, and they actually
communicate about that.
Now, you will recall that in the Cayman proceedings,
there was a change in AHAB's argumentation following the
discovery of the N files and they started changing their
case from everything is forged to now only the
facilities that increased the $2 billion debt after 2000
were potentially forged.
So there was a lot of discussion about that in the
Cayman proceedings.  There were findings that actually
this was not supported by the documentation.
Here you have exhibit C-171, which is AHAB's
spreadsheet of lending relationship which was provided
by KFH when the old KFH facilities were increased, but
not alleged to be forged in the Cayman proceedings
(The hearing adjourned until 9.30 am on the following day)
